abstract.p: Letter from Rabbi Allan Schranz of Sutton Place Synagogue comments on June 28 article on opposition by Italian Jewish community to beatification of Pope Pius IX

block.p: It is important that Jews and Catholics continue to improve relations. Much progress has been made, but the future depends on honesty and sensitivity.

In commenting on the Italian Jewish Communities' objection to the beatification of Pope Pius IX (news article, June 28), Msgr. Carlos Liberati, the Vatican official overseeing Pius's cause, said: ''The church has tried everything to improve relations with the Jews. But they don't forgive us the slightest thing.''
It is important that Jews and Catholics continue to improve relations. Much progress has been made, but the future depends on honesty and sensitivity.

In commenting on the Italian Jewish Communities' objection to the beatification of Pope Pius IX (news article, June 28), Msgr. Carlos Liberati, the Vatican official overseeing Pius's cause, said: ''The church has tried everything to improve relations with the Jews. But they don't forgive us the slightest thing.''
The ''slightest thing'' is the forced baptism and later kidnapping by the church of 6-year-old Edgardo Mortara from his Jewish parents in Bologna in 1858.
How can we ascend to higher ground when such a grievous injustice against a Jewish family and the Jewish community is dismissed as a slight thing?
ALLAN SCHRANZ Rabbi, Sutton Place Synagogue New York, June 28, 2000
